title: ‘No horoscope or magic behind mental illness’
Cities can but lack will to be disability-friendly
article: The Accessible India campaign in Gujarat's cities has remained a mixed bag in terms of making physical and digital spaces accessible to people with disabilities (PwDs). While some changes have been made after accessibility audits, compliance with universal accessibility norms is poor. A mobile app developed by Voice of Specially Abled Persons (VoSAP) provides ratings on buildings in Ahmedabad, Surat, Vadodara, and Rajkot, with only 7% receiving '5 star' facilities for PwDs. On average, 62% of buildings are inaccessible. The onus is on everyone to prioritize accessibility for all potential users, beyond PwDs.

title: Govt pushes for "Make in India' in diagnostics, rolls out IQ test to assess intellectual disability
article: The government has introduced the 'Indian Test of Intelligence' to assess intellectual disability. This IQ assessment test kit, developed by NIEPID, is approved for issuing Unique disability Identity certificates. The minister handed out UDID cards to children who underwent the test. This test kit will promote 'Make In India' diagnostics and be accessible to trained Indian psychologists. NIEPID's test is based on knowledge, reasoning, quantitative reasoning, spatial reasoning, and working memory, suitable for children aged 3-18.

title: 16 change-makers honoured with Helen Keller awards for strides towards inclusivity
article: 16 individuals and firms honored with the 24th Helen Keller Awards for fostering inclusive work environment and championing integration of disabled individuals into mainstream workforce. Winners from diverse states in India showcased commitment to inclusivity. Awards, a joint initiative of NCPEDP and LTIMindtree, empower PWDs and inspire inclusive job market. Arman Ali, executive director of NCPEDP, emphasized the Awards' role in recognizing individuals and institutions promoting employment, equality, and diversity. Debashis Chatterjee, CEO of LTIMindtree, highlighted the importance of skilling and employment opportunities for disabled individuals to integrate into the mainstream job market.

Malaika Arora keeps calm as her physically disabled fan puts his hand on her waist, bodyguard intervenes
article: One of her fans, who was physically disabled, turned to Malaika Arora to click a selfie with her, which garnered several reactions from netizens. While posing, the fan wrapped his hand around her waist which made Malaika visibly uncomfortable. However, she kept calm and continued to have a smile on her face. One of her bodyguards also intervened after she made a gesture with her hands to call him.

title: In unique punishment for delay in updation of disability status, MTNL officers directed to serve students with disabilities for 5 days
article: The Court of the Chief Commissioner of Persons with Disabilities has punished officials responsible for a four-year delay in updating the category of a Mahanagar Telephone Nigam Ltd employee. The officials will have to render five days of service to students with disabilities at Amar Jyoti Charitable Trust in Delhi. Chief commissioner Rajesh Aggarwal expressed strong dissatisfaction with the delay and set a December 31 deadline for completion. A report has been requested.

Errant officials punished, asked to serve disabled students for 5 days
article: The Court of the Chief Commissioner of Persons with Disabilities has punished officials responsible for a four-year delay in updating the category of a Mahanagar Telephone Nigam Ltd employee. The officials will have to serve five days at Amar Jyoti Charitable Trust, a Delhi institution for students with disabilities, to be sensitized on disability matters. The Chief Commissioner has set a deadline of December 31 for completing this service and has requested a report on the matter.

title: Disabled Dalit beaten up for sitting on cot
article: A 20-year-old Dalit man was brutally assaulted by four men from the Thakor community in Nedroda village. The incident occurred because the victim sat on a cot belonging to a member of the Thakor community. The assault was captured in a viral video and showed the physically handicapped Dalit man being beaten and abused. The victim, Ashwin Parmar, had a disability in his left leg since birth. The prime accused, Alpesh Vasant Thakor, along with three others, subjected Ashwin to caste-based slurs and physical violence.

title: Why disabled students want JNU to Walk The Talk
article: The Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) campus in Delhi lacks accessibility for disabled students, violating the norms set by the University Grants Commission. The campus, built on rocky terrain, has inaccessible entrances, absent ramps, and elevators, making it difficult for students with disabilities to navigate. The lack of proper infrastructure and facilities, such as tactile pavements, lifts, and ramps, hinders the daily lives of disabled students. The Disabled Students' Association (DSA) of JNU has raised concerns about the absence of infrastructure to aid visually impaired students. The university's Equal Opportunity Cell has failed to address these grievances effectively.

Delhi airport tries to make travel bright & sunny for those with hidden disabilities
article: Delhi International Airport Limited (DIAL) has introduced special services for travelers with hidden disabilities at Delhi airport. The airport has transformed into a Sunflower airport, aligned with the Hidden Disabilities Sunflower initiative. Passengers can use discreet items like lanyards, pin badges, and wristbands to signal their need for assistance. All passenger-facing staff members have undergone training on hidden disabilities to ensure a caring and supportive environment throughout the journey. The initiative is part of DIAL's commitment to providing a seamless travel experience for all passengers.

title: UP is the only state in country to have 2 varsities for disabled: CM
President Droupadi Murmu confers national awards, calls for inclusive ecosystem
article: Teen Mumbai swimmer Jia Rai, deaf designer Himanshu Kansal, visually impaired Taha ldrees Haaziq, and Amazon India were among the recipients of the annual national awards for persons with disabilities in India. The awards, presented by President Droupadi Murmu, recognized individuals and organizations for their achievements in empowerment and inclusivity. Jia Rai, an open water para swimmer, has achieved national and international fame, while Himanshu Kansal has developed innovative Indian Sign language resources.

title: ‘Make offices disabled-friendly, depute staff at ground floor to provide service’
article: The Chief Commissioner of Disabilities in India has stated that all government offices and public services must be made accessible to people with disabilities. This includes deputing staff on the ground floor and providing services in accessible areas. The recommendations were made by the Court of the Chief Commissioner for Persons with Disabilities after a disability rights activist had a difficult experience during the registration of her marriage. The court expressed concern over the insensitive handling of the matter.

title: India introduces home-based schooling for children with special needs
article: The Department of School Education and Literacy (DSEL) in India is planning to introduce home-based schooling for students with severe disabilities as part of special inclusivity measures. Under the new norms by the NCERT, an itinerant resource teacher will visit the students' homes to provide guidance and support. The initiative aims to help children with special needs, physically challenged students, and those from disadvantaged backgrounds acquire necessary learning levels. Special educators will also be appointed, and regular teachers will receive cross-disability training to better support these students. The guidelines align with the objectives of the National Education Policy (NEP) 2020.

title: Making a difference to the Margazhi music fest with inclusivity
article: The event, which puts the spotlight on disabled artistes, is organised by Dr Ranjini Kaushik. She talks to us about the importance of inclusivity and how sabhas can be more inclusive.

title: ‘Aankh Micholi’ producers, CBFC served notice over film’s content mocking disabilities
article: The court of the chief commissioner for persons with disabilities (CCPD) has issued a notice to the producers of the Hindi film 'Aankh Micholi' and the Central Board of Film Certification (CBFC) regarding the content that mocks various types of disabilities. disability rights groups have expressed concerns about the film's narrative. The CCPD has requested a reply from the filmmakers and CBFC within 10 days, stating that the film may be in violation of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016. Non-compliance could result in punishment under the Act.

title: England Physical disability team to play five IT20s in Jan-Feb in India
article: It's not just the England men's cricket team which will be in action in India early next year when it tours the country for a five-Test series. England's Men’s Physical disability team too will be playing a five I20s series in India in January and February

title: Government puts 'anganwadi' workers on the frontline to identify & track children with disabilities
article: The Centre launched the 'Anganwadi protocol' to identify disabilities in children and connect them to interventions. This protocol, focused on children with disabilities, provides training for anganwadi workers. The workers use the Poshan Tracker app to collect data and track the children. All children will be assessed for developmental delays and referred to ASHA and ANM. The protocol also supports families and encourages integration of children with disabilities into mainstream schools. Anganwadi centres will adopt a multi-sensory and toy-based approach to cater to different needs.

title: Inclusiveness on menu, shows apex court, makes space for cafe run by the disabled
article: The Supreme Court of India has allowed the opening of a cafe called 'Mitti Cafe' on its premises. The cafe, founded in 2017 by Alina Alam, aims to provide employment and training to individuals with disabilities. It has expanded to over 38 cafes and served over 2 million meals during the Covid-19 pandemic. The Chief Justice of India highlighted the importance of inclusiveness and praised the cafe for its role in promoting inclusion and empowerment. The cafe's decor reflects the talents within the disabled community.

title: Police want parents to disable this feature on their kids iPhones, here’s why
article: Apple iOS 17 introduces new features and changes, including the 'NameDrop' feature that allows easy exchange of contact information, photos, etc. A local police division in Ohio advises parents to turn off this feature to protect their kids' safety and privacy. Disabling 'NameDrop' can prevent the easy sharing of data like photos, phone numbers, and addresses. To disable 'NameDrop' on your iPhone, go to Settings, tap on General, then AirDrop, and turn off the toggle switch. Even though there is some user input required to share contact information, disabling the feature on kids' phones is a wise choice for added safety and data protection.

article: A woman named Ramya, claiming to be the boy's stepsister, along with S Babu took custody of the boy and locked out Shanthi. Shanthi's complaints to the police went in vain. A police probe revealed that Ramya's documents, including her birth and death certificates, were fake. Babu's claim of having a law degree and his certificates were also found to be fake.
